awd_titl_txt: Structure and Function of Heteroanionic Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

Twenty-first century microelectronic and battery technologies rely on components consisting of transition metal oxides that can accommodate reversible changes in the distribution of their electrons. This award supports theoretical and computational research on the fundamental science of heteroanionic materials, which are compounds consisting of more than one anion beyond oxygen such as oxynitrides, oxyfluorides, and oxysulfides. These compounds benefit from the stability of oxide materials, but have the added advantage of tunable electronic, magnetic, and topological properties owing to the additional secondary anion, which allows for greater control over the electron distribution.

The project goals are to design, discover, and control the properties of heteroanionic materials displaying ferroelectricity, metal-insulator transitions, and topological band structures by establishing links between crystal structure and anion chemistry, profiting from a coupling of theory, simulation, and comprehensive experimentation. The project utilizes quantum-mechanical based calculations to establish model frameworks and knowledge that are both descriptive and predictive. These models and approaches may be expanded to materials beyond heteroanionic materials, enabling an unprecedented expansion of compounds with varying electronic functions for future technologies.

The teaching and training of students and the discovery capabilities of the project are also interwoven and aimed at broadening participation of underrepresented students in Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics disciplines through public outreach events, through undergraduate and graduate curriculum development, and by involving students with experiential and interdisciplinary training. The educational impact extends to high-school students by developing materials physics/engineering modules that meet Next Generation Science Standards in concert with high school teachers.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Complex transition metal oxides are utilized in a variety of technologies owing to their properties ranging from ferroelectricity to high-temperature superconductivity supported by polarizable oxide anions. The design, discovery, and control of new transition metal compounds, particularly those with multiple anions (heteroanionic materials) rather than multiple cations (homoanionic oxides with a single anion), with novel properties and superior performance are crucial to the continued development of present and future technologies. This award supports theoretical and computational research on the fundamental science of heteroanionic materials such as oxynitrides, oxyfluorides, and oxysulfides.

The project goals are to implement and extend a heteroanionic materials design scheme for understanding the complex interplay among atomic structure, anion order, and band structure on novel electronic and quantum states and to advance new heteroanionic materials exhibiting superior functionalities and/or responses not found in homoanionic materials. The project utilizes a computational strategy, which integrates group theoretical techniques, derivative-structure tools, and density functional theory, to understand the electronic and optical properties of oxynitrides, oxyfluorides, and oxysulfides within three thrusts focused on (i) geometric and chemical control of noncentrosymmetry for acentric function; (ii) probing metal-insulator transition mechanisms for materials discovery; and (iii) novel routes to anion-ordered topological semimetals. 

The project will deliver new knowledge to facilitate the selection and design of materials with tunable electronic states derived from multiple anions. It benefits society by advancing the repertoire of structure-based design strategies to control electronic properties, which could lead to discovery of reconfigurable materials for low-power and brain-inspired microelectronics, transparent optoelectronics, and quantum information systems. In addition, educational goals of the project include the teaching and training of students at multiple levels and broadening STEM participation by underrepresented students. These goals extend to high-school students by developing materials physics/engineering modules in concert with high school teachers that meet Next Generation Science Standards. These efforts will impact the next-generation workforce by endowing students and teachers problem-solving skills to be success in globally competitive careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Traditional methods for directing the properties of inorganic oxides primarily involve cation substitution and interfacial effects in thin films and superlattices. These methods offer limited control due to the reliance on a single (oxygen) anion, which impedes materials discovery. This project focused on the design, discovery, and control of new transition metal compounds (TMCs), particularly those with multiple anions (heteroanionic materials, HAMs), rather than multiple cations (e.g., homoanionic oxides with a single anion). These materials exhibit novel properties and superior performance, which are crucial for the advancement of current and future technologies to maintain American competitiveness.

The project employed computational materials science methods to investigate the electronic and optical properties of oxynitrides, oxyfluorides, and oxysulfides. The research was organized into three thrusts: geometric and chemical control of noncentrosymmetry for acentric function, probing metal-insulator transition mechanisms for materials discovery, and exploring topological semimetals. Key intellectual merit accomplishments include:

  • Formulating new mechanisms to lift inversion symmetry in heteroanionic materials, achieving ferroelectricity, discovering Leggett modes in crystallographic transitions, and identifying novel magnetoelectrics.
  • Investigating metal-insulator transition mechanisms and magnetism in ordered oxygen vacancy compounds and oxyhalides.
  • Enhancing the understanding of how strain and chemical substitution influence local structure-property relationships among heteroleptic units.
  • Designing nonlinear optical functions in HAMs, with second-harmonic generation (SHG) properties of five new compounds either predicted or validated through experimentation by PI James Rondinelli's collaborators.

Broader Impacts

The project's findings were disseminated through scholarly publications and PhD dissertations. These developments in the design, simulation, and understanding of functional electronic materials were integrated into educational and outreach activities targeting graduate and undergraduate students, high school teachers, K-12 students, and the general public. Specific broader impacts include:

  • PhD Student Training: The project provided partial to full support for seven PhD students in Materials Science and Engineering, including two female students and one underrepresented minority. It also offered interdisciplinary, inter-institutional experiences, such as joint advising and work in experimental laboratories. These students also coordinated events among MSE graduate students and faculty to foster deeper connections and a more inclusive environment within the department.
  • Undergraduate Student Training: Five undergraduate researchers, including one female student, participated in the project through Research Experience for Undergraduates and related academic programs.
  • Curriculum Development: PI James Rondinelli, as Director of the Predictive Science and Engineering Design Program, provided interdisciplinary research opportunities for graduate students through the simulation and design of innovative, complex engineered systems. He also incorporated materials discovered and computational methods used in this project to enhance the STEM curriculum in a computational materials science course at Northwestern University, focusing on computational thinking and codesign.
  • High School Teacher Training: PI James Rondinelli mentored one female underrepresented minority teacher from Ohio, who teaches at a school serving students with dyslexia, executive function difficulties, and attention issues. They developed accurate, 3D-printable models based on electronic structures simulations of molecules. These kits were used in a 7th-grade classroom to meet NGSS standard MS-PS1-1, providing a tactile experience that improved learning outcomes.
  • Pre-College Education and Outreach: PI James Rondinelli, as Chief Advisor for Tau Beta Pi (undergraduate engineering honor society), coordinated a community engineering fair with Youth & Opportunity United, which aims to close the opportunity gap by preparing youth for post-secondary and life success. He also participated in the Quantum To-Go initiative of the American Physical Society, partnering with 3rd-grade teachers in Tucson, Arizona, to virtually visit 36 students across two classes and share his experience with quantum science and technology and future career opportunities in the STEM workforce. Additionally, students in the Rondinelli group organized professional development opportunities through the Science Policy Outreach Task Force (SPOT), a nonpartisan NU organization advocating for science to the voting-aged public and policymakers.
